title: 111_hr2684
content: The Act is titled the "National Hate Crimes Hotline Act of 2009" and includes findings related to hate crimes. Congress makes findings related to hate crimes, including the brutal murders of Jose Sucuzhanay and Marcelo Lucero in 2008. The indictment revealed that a group of boys targeted Marcelo Lucero, a Hispanic man, with racist slurs before beating and murdering him. Hate groups in the US have increased by 54% in the past 8 years, with a rise in hate crimes against various minority groups reported by the FBI. Attacks on Hispanics grew by 40% from 2003 to 2007, despite a smaller population increase. The text chunk "SEC. 3. NATIONAL HATE CRIME HOTLINE AND HATE CRIME INFORMATION AND ASSISTANCE WEBSITE." is about the establishment of a national hate crime hotline and website for providing information and assistance related to hate crimes. The Attorney General may award grants to private, nonprofit entities to establish a national hate crime hotline and a secure Internet website for victims of hate crimes. Grants can last up to 5 years and are subject to annual approval and availability of funds. An entity receiving a grant under this section must use funds to establish and operate a national hate crime hotline, including contracting with a carrier for a toll-free line, training personnel to provide counseling and referral services 24/7, and maintaining a database of services for victims of hate crimes. The entity receiving a grant must use funds to establish a national hate crime hotline, publicize it, and provide grants for a hate crime information website. Callers cannot be asked about their citizenship status. The hate crime information and assistance website must provide accurate information on services available to victims, including health care, mental health, social services, and transportation. Service providers are not required to be linked to the website. The Attorney General must approve grant applications for funding. To be approved for a grant by the Attorney General, an application must contain agreements, assurances, and information in the prescribed form. For activities related to a national hate crime hotline, the application must include a detailed plan for the hotline's operation, including training programs and hiring criteria for personnel. The application for a grant to operate a national hate crime hotline must include details such as hiring criteria for hotline personnel, methods for maintaining a resource database, publicizing the hotline, providing service to non-English speakers and those with hearing impairments, and a plan for developing and updating information and resources. The applicant for a grant to operate a hate crime hotline must demonstrate expertise in hate crimes, support from advocacy groups, and a plan to secure funding for the website's continued operation after the third year. The applicant for a hate crime hotline grant must show expertise in hate crimes, support from advocacy groups, commitment to diversity, and provision of services to various minorities. A hate crime is defined as intentionally targeting a victim based on race, religion, gender, disability, or sexual orientation. Authorization of Appropriations: $3,500,000 authorized annually for hate crime hotline grants from 2010 to 2014. 10% of funds allocated for website purposes. Funds may remain available until expended. The Attorney General may award grants to State and local law enforcement entities for educational and training programs on hate crime prevention and community dialogues with at-risk groups. Entities must comply with reporting requirements under the Hate Crimes Statistics Act to be eligible. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2010 and beyond. The Attorney General can award grants to organizations for local programs serving victims of hate crimes in targeted areas. Grant funds can be used for hiring counselors, providing training, resources, and support services. Targeted areas are defined as lacking resources for hate crime victims. Funding for grants awarded under this section cannot be used by organizations that discriminate based on religion or for promoting religious beliefs. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal year 2010 and beyond.
